definitions: act against something or respond to an action with an opposing action or argument
move or act in a direction opposite to something else
examples: The lawyer countered every argument with solid evidence and facts
She countered his criticism by pointing out his own mistakes
The boxer countered left when his opponent moved right quickly
The ship had to counter the strong currents pushing eastward

definitions: strike or beat someone or something with a whip or similar instrument
move or go somewhere very quickly and suddenly with force
beat cream, eggs, or similar ingredients rapidly to make them light and fluffy
examples: The cruel master would whip the horses to make them run
The wind whipped the rain against the window all night
She whipped around the corner before anyone could see her
He whipped out his phone to capture the amazing sunset
Please whip the cream until it forms stiff peaks for dessert
The chef whipped the egg whites for the delicate souffle recipe

definitions: cause or bring about a particular state, condition, or effect through deliberate action
persuade or influence someone to do something through reasoning or incentives
examples: The medication can induce drowsiness in some patients taking it regularly
Stress can induce physical symptoms like headaches and stomach problems
They tried to induce him to join their company with benefits
Nothing could induce her to change her mind about moving away

definitions: produce sparks of fire or electricity through friction or electrical discharge
trigger, stimulate, or cause something to begin or develop suddenly
examples: The wires sparked dangerously when they touched each other in rain
Rubbing the stones together will spark a fire for warmth tonight
Her speech sparked a heated debate about education reform nationwide
The new discovery sparked interest among scientists around the world

definitions: blow air on something or someone using a fan or similar waving motion
spread out or cause to spread out in a fan-like shape or pattern
examples: She fanned herself with a magazine in the hot waiting room
The servants fanned the king with large palm leaves all day
The peacock fanned its tail feathers to attract a mate nearby
The cards fanned out perfectly in the magician's skilled hands

definitions: impose a compulsory financial charge or levy on income, property, or goods
make heavy demands on someone's strength, resources, or abilities
examples: The government decided to tax luxury goods at a higher rate
They plan to tax carbon emissions to fight climate change effectively
The long hike really taxed our endurance in the summer heat
Caring for elderly parents can tax your emotional and financial resources

definitions: remove the outer covering or skin from a fruit, vegetable, or similar object
come off or fall away from a surface in strips, layers, or flakes
examples: Please peel the potatoes before adding them to the soup pot
She carefully peeled the orange without breaking the skin into pieces
The old paint began to peel from the walls after years
His sunburned skin started to peel after a week at beach

definitions: organize and carry out a series of planned activities to achieve a political or social goal
conduct a series of military operations in a particular area to achieve an objective
examples: The senator will campaign across the state for the upcoming election
Environmental groups campaign actively against deforestation in the Amazon rainforest
The general planned to campaign through the winter despite harsh conditions
Napoleon's army campaigned across Europe for over a decade successfully

definitions: bite and grind food in the mouth with teeth to make it easier to swallow
think about or consider something carefully and thoroughly over time
examples: Remember to chew your food slowly for better digestion and health
The dog loves to chew on bones for hours every afternoon
Let me chew on that proposal before giving you my final answer
She needed time to chew over the difficult decision about college

definitions: enter a country or territory by force with an army to conquer or occupy it
intrude on or encroach upon someone's privacy, space, or rights without permission
examples: The enemy forces planned to invade at dawn from the north
In 1066, William the Conqueror invaded England and changed history forever
Please don't invade my personal space when we're talking at work
Weeds can quickly invade a garden if not controlled properly

definitions: remove or take out something from a particular place or container with effort
obtain a substance or information from something by a special process or method
examples: The dentist had to extract two wisdom teeth during the procedure
Use tweezers to extract the splinter from your finger carefully
Scientists extract DNA from ancient bones for genetic research studies
The journalist managed to extract the truth from the reluctant witness

definitions: encourage or promote the development or growth of something positive or beneficial
take care of and bring up a child that is not one's own by birth
examples: Good teachers foster creativity and critical thinking in their students daily
The program aims to foster better understanding between different cultural groups
They decided to foster children who needed a safe, loving home
The family fostered three siblings until they found permanent placement

definitions: cause someone to lose confidence, enthusiasm, or hope about doing something
try to prevent something from happening by showing disapproval or creating obstacles
examples: Don't let one failure discourage you from pursuing your dreams passionately
The constant criticism began to discourage even the most enthusiastic students
The high prices discourage people from eating at that expensive restaurant
New regulations discourage smoking in all public spaces and buildings

definitions: improve something to a newer, better, or more advanced version or standard
raise someone or something to a higher grade, rank, or level of importance
examples: We need to upgrade our computer systems to handle more data
The airline offered to upgrade us to first class for free
The storm was upgraded to a category 4 hurricane overnight
After excellent performance, she was upgraded to senior manager position

definitions: allow liquid, gas, or light to escape gradually through a hole or crack
intentionally disclose secret or confidential information to the public or media
examples: The roof started to leak during the heavy rainstorm last night
Oil began to leak from the damaged pipe under the car
Someone leaked the confidential report to the press before publication
Government officials worry that employees might leak sensitive security information

definitions: become or make smaller in size, amount, or value through natural process or treatment
draw back or move away from something through fear, dislike, or reluctance
examples: Cotton clothes tend to shrink when washed in hot water repeatedly
The company had to shrink its workforce during the economic downturn
She would shrink from any form of physical confrontation or conflict
He shrank back when the angry dog barked at him loudly

definitions: talk in a friendly and informal way about unimportant or everyday matters
examples: We love to chat over coffee every Sunday morning at cafe
The neighbors often chat about the weather across the garden fence

definitions: place or arrange things in a straight line or in correct relative positions
give support to a person, organization, or cause by associating with them publicly
examples: Please align all the chairs in straight rows for the ceremony
The mechanic needs to align your car's wheels for smooth driving
The company decided to align itself with environmental protection groups
Several nations aligned with each other to form a trade alliance

definitions: continue firmly in a course of action despite difficulty, opposition, or failure
examples: She persisted in her studies despite facing numerous financial hardships
If symptoms persist for more than a week, consult your doctor
